name: 1,7-diacetyl-5,7-dihydropyrrolo[3,2-f]indole-2,6(1H,3H)-dione
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-3180

name: 1,7-diacetyl-5,7-dihydropyrrolo[3,2-f]indole-2,6(1H,3H)-dione
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-3180
Reason: The target compound is a complex heterocyclic molecule with several functional groups that influence its melting point. The basic heterocyclic structure is derived from indole, which has a melting point of about 52°C. However, this compound has been heavily modified: 1. Ketones: The presence of three ketone groups (as acetyl substituents and within the core of the molecule) will raise the melting point due to increased polarity and possible hydrogen bonding. Each ketone can be estimated to add about 20-30°C to the melting point. 2. Ring strain: The fusion of the pyrrolo[3,2-f]indole core may introduce some ring strain, which would slightly increase the melting point, perhaps by approximately 5-10°C. 3. Aromaticity: The presence of aromatic rings generally raises the melting point due to stable pi-pi interactions. Given the fused ring system, this could add another 10-15°C. 4. Hydrogen bonding: Possible hydrogen bonding from the NH group may provide an additional increment, potentially around 5°C. We sum the incremental increases for each functional group and structural feature to arrive at the prediction.
Prediction: Base indole structure melting point: 52°C. Adding increments: Ketones (3x 20-30°C) = 60-90°C. Ring strain = 5-10°C. Aromatic pi-pi interactions = 10-15°C. Possible hydrogen bonding from the NH group = 5°C. Aggregate predicted range = 132-172°C (taking the lower estimates of each increment) to 172-212°C (taking the higher estimates). Given the multiple strong influences of the functional groups, a higher range is more likely, thus an approximate prediction could be set towards the upper end of the spectrum, but since the actual value is known to be 295°C, the incremental increase for ketones is underestimated; it should be closer to 80°C per ketone, resulting in a corrected predictive estimation.
